body: Nice now please sqUash your commits and provide a proper commit message per guidelines. That we can put it in the next release. Thanks for your patience.

@bolkedebruin, yes, I will just not mark the imports as `# noqa`. The reason I was a little slow is that in the process I noticed those tests are never run. So it shouldn't be a blocker either way. The test I added passes locally.

@bolkedebruin @aoen PTAL.

I will try to fix the tests in a separate PR.

My understanding was that **skipped == success**, because when a skipped reaches the end the DAG is marked as success (even with half of my tasks unfinished). And actually this commit 2630361ca24737c28f458825b20ab11c9c996b17 convinced my that I had it right. That's why I wrote this PR.

I understand your point because you actually look at it from the schedulers point of view, I look at it from the users point of view. I already know 2 people in my team that fell into the trap with join nodes. And **documenting it alone isn't enough**, I would then be **prepared to change** this PR into a **raise when we detect** this with ALL_SUCCESS trigger.

Still the first DAG I wrote will never work with the only alternative I have (ONE_SUCCESS), because the branch operator starts a branch that fans out to a lot of parallel tasks that all join together to the same node where the skipped branch arrive. This will never work with the ONE_SUCESS because as soon as one of the parallel branches succeed the rest will just stop. I know I **can hack around this** by introducing a DummyOperator where all successful branches arrive, but I feel dirty if I need to do this.

So I propose this:

- I'll change this PR so the ALL_SUCCESS raises and error.
- Start on another PR that introduces 2 new triggers:
-- ALL_SUCCESS_OR_SKIPPED
-- ALL_FAILED_OR_SKIPPED

What do you think?
@bolkedebruin, please take a look.
It might be smart to move this discussion to allow others the chime in?
Moved to the mailinglist
Please also make sure to have a proper commit message per guidelines.

LGTM +1

Hi @bolkedebruin 

I changed the zone parameter to be required and adopted the logging.info method. However, I also feel that the INFO level is more appropriate to follow the task progress.

Another question: I see that that you adhere to the 90 characters limit for line lengths (original PEP-8 recommendation). However, I believe that sometimes this is bad for code readability... A lot of modern open source projects have already extended the limit to 120 characters (which is also the default in IDE's like pycharm). What do you think of this?

Thanks,
Bob
Please add a test covering this.
+1 let me merge that one for you

@bolkedebruin I think it's good, if we get +1 for @criccomini I'll merge it in before tonight. I want to build a new alpha to run on our environment and would like to have this one and the other included.
Now if @criccomini doesn't look this one over by tonight I like to merge this one anyway so I can build a new version on-top of master for the final freeze.
Resolved in celery>=4.0.1 (4.0.0 fails)
Some minor nits. Please correct and I'll merge.

@msumit The code as written is not a SAML login method; but instead just off loads the authentication to Okta (kind of like ldap/ad/radius auth checks). This code would not be re-usable by other SAML providers;

(Not the author, not a member of the airflow project, just reviewing the commit)

@argh128 that's not completely correct.. In general (if not all) saml providers works on a `custom_url` and `api_key` concept, given these 2 values and any provider would be able to do saml authorization for you..

My comment is more that this is not generalizable, and is not using a saml assertion, so trying to call it saml_auth or having it be configurable for multiple providers is not really possible with the way this PR is constructed. It does do what Bryan requested which is a simple way to route the authentication to Okta. 

IMO, I would use the sample code from OneLogin https://github.com/onelogin/python-saml/blob/master/demo-flask/index.py as a base which does use saml, and thus could be generalized to multiple providers. 

The code as written is very specific to Okta, because Okta provides an authentication API that allows you to check if a username/password matches the okta password credentials. It would not work in our environment because we require 2FA which would then require a second factor check that further makes this Okta specific.

I should also mention that at least onelogin also provides a mechanism like the one your thinking for auth https://developers.onelogin.com/api-docs/1/users/create-session-login-token

But besides it using a token, password and username has little resemblance to the okta one.

Sorry all. Been side tracked on other stuff, but +1 anyway. :)

The default time isn't necessarily the configured time, and also the loop is bottlenecked by the slowest-parsing DAG/the dag parsing timeout so I still think this change makes sense.

pls let me know your thought and whether we can collaborate on this.  Thanks

@aoen I agree that it is nice to have, but there are some caveats and concerns that are not addressed yet. As such for 1.8 I don't think it should go in as is.
@jhsenjaliya Absolutely! I actually thought the same thing.  Please use [this pull request](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1992) instead.
@jhsenjaliya - I would assume that the SftpHook actually should be named SshHook because it returns SSHClient. So I am up for merging these. What do you think?
yes, you are right, let me share my code regarding the same, and we can collaborate more on how to accommodate both into ssh operator, Thanks !

@jhsenjaliya I pushed some changes [here](https://github.com/genomics-geek/incubator-airflow/tree/feature-sftp). Feel free to add to it. I don't love the way I am handling put/get at the moment, so let me know if you have more thoughts about it as well! 

Also, we need to update unit tests / integration tests. Any ideas?

@genomics-geek @jhsenjaliya Is this new implementation of a merged SSHOperator+SftpOperator will be able to open an SSH Tunnel throughout the whole DAG execution without the need to call SSHOperator each time an SSH connection is needed? If not maybe this is also an idea worth to be implemented.
I have tried but without success.

Another thing is this new operator will filter out some directories/files when copying from the server? using some regex expressions on the directory/file names or creation date,...

Overall i think its a good idea to merge the both +1
@jhsenjaliya had the ability to open SSH tunnels before. I believe @jhsenjaliya will add it into this refactoring :). we both were moving to use the paramiko library.

I'm not sure that help will get this out any faster, it's just a tad slow to test at the moment, in that I need to run the impersonation tests through the travis environment to make sure they are compatible and there is no way to do this without running the CI suite. I guess there are some parts that can be parallelized (e.g. documentation), but I don't really think it's fair to push those things onto others. I think once the travis compatibility work is completed, the other issues are much smaller (pending yak-shaving).

Airbnb is more than willing to help test (which I think is quite helpful for the release considering our extensive staging environment), so I think it's worth it for the community to wait for this to get this merged in before releasing.

@bolkedebruin please can it be included before the beta. 0 risk for functionality and it pairs with a recently added Google Cloud feature. Making it complete.

Integration tests are available at https://github.com/alexvanboxel/airflow-gcp-examples

> Just came to my mind: I think we should add a config option whether to support "run_as". Some might want to disable it.

Do you mean to prevent user error? If so this can be done in a company's CI processes if necessary (e.g. check if DAGs have run_as set and fail if so). run_as is always more restrictive than the current airflow user so it should be strictly safer, and users can bypass this flag with a BashOperator that does a "sudo su". I like to avoid adding configuration unless it is really necessary to reduce complexity (for both users and maintainers). What do you think?

> Do you mean to prevent user error? If so this can be done in a company's CI processes if necessary (e.g. check if DAGs have run_as set and fail if so). run_as is always more restrictive than the current airflow user so it should be strictly safer, and users can bypass this flag with a BashOperator that does a "sudo su". I like to avoid adding configuration unless it is really necessary to reduce complexity (for both users and maintainers). What do you think?

I'm looking from the perspective of a corporate policy. Ie. I might want to disable the functionality entirely because I don't trust my users. "run_as" is pretty powerful.

Without run_as users would be running their tasks at the highest airflow privilege , so couldn't they still accomplish this `run_as` behavior even with the policy by having a BashOperator with something like "sudo su -u SomeOtherUser"?

> Without run_as users would be running their tasks at the highest airflow privilege , so couldn't they still accomplish this run_as behavior even with the policy by having a BashOperator with something like "sudo su -u SomeOtherUser"?

Haha that makes sense. Good point. The sudoers policy should prevent it (or make it possible). That needs to be documented well!

> Haha that makes sense. Good point. The sudoers policy should prevent it (or make it possible). That needs to be documented well!

What should the sudoers policy prevent?

> What should the sudoers policy prevent?

By default it prevents "sudo" rights you need to configure it to allow elevating rights or to become someone else.

Fair enough! My only concern is that a change like this will be harder to merge later (the merging effort will become significant).
